Award.AwardTitle: EARS: Collaborative Research: Big Bandwidth: Finding Anomalous Needles in the Spectrum Haystack

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective:
The objective of the proposed project is to explore the problem of scanning large amounts of spectrum in order to detect anomalous usage of that spectrum. The project will examine spectrum scanning using a single spectrum sensor and using multiple spectrum sensors. The approach will involve using game theoretic formulations that allow for the determination of scanning strategies that give an optimal likelihood of detecting an adversarial or accidental misuse of spectrum in terms of the bandwidth that can be scanned in a single scan and the bandwidth that an anomalous activity might involve. The optimization of strategies are complemented by techniques that increase the amount of spectrum that can be scanned in a single scan, and spectrum mapping algorithms that estimate the received power levels at arbitrary spatial locations.

Intellectual merit:
The intellectual merit of the proposed effort stems from the pulling together of a mixture of technologies from different fields, including game theory, signal processing, security, wireless communications, and RF photonics to address the challenging problem of detecting and preventing anomalous spectrum activity across a wide swath of bandwidth.

Broader impacts:
The broader impacts of the proposed effort will include the cross-pollination between different disciplines, such as game theory, security, photonics and signal processing. Additionally, the project will guide the development of graduate and undergraduate students at both participating institutions, giving the students new tools with which to contribute to wireless and optical communications. Finally, new interdisciplinary curricula will be developed as part of the effort.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The BigBandwidth project was concerned with developing tools that can facilitate the detection of anomalous, unwanted radio signals in the nation's communication spectrum. This challenge is difficult as there is significant spectrum to scan, thus leading to an engineering problem of "finding a needle in the haystack". To address this significant challenge, the project involved several new technical contributions, including: (1) developing efficient spectrum scanning algorithms that could be easily implemented in software, (2) developing algorithms that could construct a spectrum usage map that would use a small set of sensors to infer spectrum activity at locations where there were no sensors; and (3) to explore the various tradeoffs that exist between traditional electrical analog-to-digital hardware and the use of photonic circuitry that could facilitate scanning entirely in hardware. 

A core contribution of the project was that it advanced the science behind spectrum scanning from the point of view that it incorporated an adversary in the model. In particular, it was recognized that the introduction of anomalous signals into radio spectrum is likely an adversarial activity in which the misbehavior either had the objective to avoid being detected, to cause interference on legitimate radio spectrum, or to seek economic benefit from the illicit use of radio spectrum. The project developed a thorough mathematical framework that allows one to model these different adversarial objectives, and derive optimal spectrum scanning policies for a single spectrum scanner and/or multiple spectrum scanners. Further, the algorithmic framework was extendible in the sense that it also allows for one to incorporate additional, realistic constraints such as the the fact that different radio transceivers might have different sensitivites, and hence different detection characteristics. A software framework for spectrum scanning using software defined radios was developed during the scope of these projects. This software framework was used to validate someofthe spectrum sensing algorithms developed in the project. 

The project also resulted in significant advancement to the field of radio propagation modeling and spectrum interpolation. In particular, the team developed an approach by which it is possible to more efficiently model the effect of interference on the performance of a communication system using a reduced-tap model for the fading environment. This efficient model was shown to reduce computation by a factor of two, while yielding statistically equivalent simulation results Additionally, the effort resulted in the development of a path loss-based interpolation scheme that can accurately estimate the power levels at locations bounded by four spectrum sensors deployed in a rectangular pattern.  A family of three different pathloss-based interpolation schemes were developed in this project, and thorough performance analysis of these three different local pathloss-based interpolation schemes was performed. These different interpolation schemes were shown to have computational and performance benefits compared to a  family of other approaches in the literature.
